Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Laplace transform in signal processing, where the input signal \\( x(t) \\) is transformed into \\( X(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{x(t)\\}(s) \\). We explore the effects of pre-multiplying the input signal by a modulation function \\( m(t) = e^{at} \\), where \\( a \\) is a real number.

Knowing the transformed result \\( X(s) \\), can we infer the original signal \\( x(t) \\) without knowing whether \\( m(t) = e^{at} \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without certainty if the modulation \\( m(t) \\) was applied, one would not know to adjust the Laplace variable \\( s \\) by \\( a \\) (i.e., transforming \\( X(s+a) \\) back to \\( X(s) \\)). Incorrectly assuming the presence or absence of modulation results in an incorrect inverse transformation, hence an incorrect inference of \\( x(t) \\).
